content: A central bank canseek to influence the level and shape of the yield curve by acting on two components of the longterm interest rates: the expectations component and the term premium. The expectationscomponent reflects market expectations of the future path of the policy-controlled short-terminterest rates. All else equal, a path that is lower and shallower tends to produce a lower level oflong-term yields and a flatter curve. The term premium reflects the excess return that an investordemands as a compensation for holding a bond with a long, say ten-year, residual maturityrelative to rolling over a short-term bill for ten years.
